For the last 30 years, the scientific research literature has been formally addressing the topic of ‘Wisdom’, especially as Western economies begin to transition from a Manufacturing & Industry Age model into a Science & Technology Information Age model.
  +   +
‘'''W'''isdom’, from a scientific perspective, as viewed as an integral component of the ‘'''D'''ata’ to ‘'''I'''nformation’ to ‘'''K'''nowledge’ learning pathway.
  +   +
The word ‘[[science]]’ derives from the latin term ‘scientia’, meaning ‘having knowledge’.
  +
Scientically, ‘Knowledge’ lies along a continuum between ‘Information / Data’ and ‘Wisdom’.
  +   +
Collectively, these inter-related hierarchical elements are termed the ‘[['''DIKW''']]’ scientific learning pathway.
  +   +
'''K'''nowledge, from a scientific perspective, is generally viewed as ‘the ability to predict response-patterns, based upon evidence collected by the [[scientific method’]]. All scientific knowledge is derived from scientific ‘Information’: Some experts define scientific ‘knowledge’ as ‘information in context’.
  +   +
'''I'''nformation, from a scientific perspective, is a configuration of data, collected by the scientific method, that reveals new significant relationships. Functionally, scientific ‘information’ tends to be experienced as ‘a demand upon the observer’s attention’. Some experts define scientific ‘information’ as ‘data in context’.
  +   +
'''D'''ata, in turn, is viewed by scientists as the ‘infinite facts of the universe’, and thus forms the root basis of all scientific observation and discovery.
  +   +
‘'''W'''isdom’, from a scientific perspective, could be viewed simply as ‘knowledge in context’. Yet functionally, ‘'''W'''isdom’ is far more textured and multidimensional.
  +
The modern western scientist who has conducted the most visible and thoughtful research on this topic is [[Jonas Salk]], in his companion reports “[[Survival Of The Wisest]]” and “[Anatomy Of Reality]”. In his research, Salk operationally defines the scientific experience of ‘'''W'''isdom’ in this way (paraphrased):
  +
  +
1. The acquisition of scientific mastery & competency, based upon an authentic appreciation of the field;
  +   +
2. The acquisition of scientific purpose;
  +
  +
3. The acquisition of skills for improving the knowledge-, learning-, and value-creation-assets of one’s scientific community-of-practice; and
  +   +
4. The ability to create timely scientific solutions that are pleasing to Man, while not being in violation of the timeless laws of Nature.
  +   +
In its simplest form, Salk summarized his scientific research on ‘Wisdom’ with the “'''Good Ancestor Principle'''”:
  +   +
'''''“…the most important question we must ask ourselves is ‘Are we being good ancestors?’ Given the rapidly changing discoveries and conditions of the time, this opens up a crucial conversation – just what will it take for our descendants to look back upon our decisions today and judge us good ancestors?”'''''
  +
